Award.AwardTitle: Spatially Patterned Nano/Microparticles to Traverse Biological Barriers
Award.AbstractNarration:
Non-Technical: This award by the Biomaterials program in the Division of Materials Research is to create and study novel multifunctional particles which mimic bacterial processes for beneficial purposes such as drug delivery. The biomaterial is based upon a newly created form of Janus particle, which displays biological ligands on a particle in a spatially distinct manner, for example with a right and left hemisphere. Since the particle ligands are clustered and polarized, highly effective biological reactions can be harnessed by the particle to enter cells and translocate within cells. Interactions of the particles with a model of the blood brain barrier will be studied to understand the efficiency of particle delivery to the brain. This project will provide interdisciplinary training opportunities to graduate and undergraduate students on biomaterials, microtechnology, and neuroscience. The research activities will also promote the recruitment and mentoring of diverse students in cutting-edge scientific techniques through outreach in the Atlanta public high schools.


Technical: Particles that can actively traverse biological barriers, such as the blood-brain barrier, would be highly beneficial for a variety of basic science and applied purposes. Traversing biological barriers is routinely demonstrated by some pathogens. For example, the bacterium Listeria monocytogenes can asymmetrically express specific proteins to efficiently internalize into cells, escape a phagosome, and actuate within the cell cytosol via nucleated actin polymerization to escape the cell. However, designing biomaterials that can accomplish these tasks is a challenge. This study aims to create new, multifunctional particles which mimic pathogenic mechanisms to enter an epithelial cell layer and actively transport within the cell to exit on the basal side. Janus particles will be designed as a new class of multifunctional, topographically distinct particles that can autonomously transverse an epithelial barrier. These particles will be created with micropatterning technologies to produce chemically-distinct regions on the particle surface to which effector proteins are linked to mediate each step of transcytosis. The investigators hypothesize that high density of effector ligands through topographic separation will engineer particles with potent and coordinated ligand-mediated processes characteristically achieved by biological organisms. Interactions of the particles with a model of the blood brain barrier will be studied to understand the efficiency of particle delivery to and within the brain. The proposed program will help inspire graduate and undergraduate students from diverse disciplines and backgrounds to study how microfabrication technologies can harness bio-inspired effectors to create new biomimetic materials to widely impact the biosciences. Additionally the program will develop new curriculum for engineers and scientists to design multifunctional particles, which will further include the recruiting of high school students and teachers to contribute to research studies.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Particles that display multifunctional regions can be important to perform functions such as recognition, catalysis, detection, and motion, similar to more complicated organisms as demonstrated by some pathogens. However, designing biomaterials that can accomplish complex tasks is a challenge. The objective of this research is to create spatially patterned multifunctional particles which mimic complex biological processes, including detection of local biological signals. These particles were created with micropatterning technologies to produce chemically-distinct regions on the particle surface to which we conjugate effector proteins. We hypothesized that high density of effector ligands through topographic separation will lead to particles with potent and coordinated ligand-mediated processes.

In the first objective, we designed multifuctional particles with spatially segregated effector proteins. To create multifunctional biomaterials, we leveraged micropatterning technology and orthogonal biochemical functionalization. We designed Janus particles to be multifunctional, topographically distinct smart particles that can perform functions such as collect locally secreted biological signals. We tested metal vapor shadowing methods to create particles with two and three chemically distinct regions. We demonstrated an orthogonal biochemical linking strategy so that protein effectors can be covalently attached to particles in a spatially defined manner with little cross-specificity.

In the second objective, we designed cancer targeting particles that simultaneously activate local cytotoxic immune cells. Cytotoxic T cells are effector immune cells which recognize antigens on cancer cells, bind strongly to these cells, and secrete cytolytic granules containing perforin and granzymes. The secretion causes the target cell to undergo apoptosis and die. The ability to activate these immune cells within the immunosuppressive tumor microenvironment is critically important to improve immune responses to cancer. We designed particles with common immune activating molecules and anti-folate receptor antibody on each Janus particle. We found that Janus particles are capable of activating T cells, snf electively bind and induce cytotoxic responses to the cancer cells.

In objective 3, we designed particles capable of targeting B cells to collect secreted antibody as a single cell secretome sensor. Antibody secreting cells (ASCs, or plasma cells) are cellular factories responsible for secreting serum antibodies. Microbial-specific ASCs can survive for a lifetime in the body and provide long-lasting protection from repeat infections. Identifying microbial-specific plasma cells is extremely difficult as terminally differentiated effector B plasma cells no longer express the surface antibody. The third objective is to design and test Janus particles as a platform for collection of ASCs specific for a microbe. One surface of the particle is designed to attach directly to ASCs. The second surface collects secreted antibody via Protein G, a high-affinity binder of IgG molecules. We found that the proximity of attached Janus particles leads to preferential collection of antibodies uniquely secreted from each individual ASC. These particles were used as sensors to specific ASCs within a flow cytometry platform using the binding of fluorescently tagged antigen.

The intellectual merit outcomes of the project, described specifically in the objectives described above, are summarized in 6 publications listed here:

 

1.     BA Holt, et al.. Fc microparticles can modulate the physical extent and magnitude of complement activity. Biomaterials Science (2017).

2.     BA Holt, et al.. Aqueous zinc compounds as residual antimicrobial agents for textiles. ACS applied materials & interfaces (2018).

3.     Aaron C. Enten, et al., Optimizing Flux Capacity of Dead-end Filtration Membranes by Controlling Flow with Pulse Width Modulated Periodic Backflush. Scientific Reports (2020). 

4.     Katily Ramirez, et al. Optimization of microbead reagents to collect and detect antibody. Langmuir (2019). 

5.     Katily Ramirez, et al. “Heterofunctional particles as single cell sensors to capture secreted immunoglobulins to isolate antigen-specific plasma cells” Advanced Healthcare Materials (2021). 

6.     Elizabeth A. Campbell, et al., Tuning Antibody Presentation to Enhance T cell Activation for Downstream Cytotoxicity Langmuir (2021).

The broader impacts include education objectives that seek to motivate and inspire graduate and undergraduate students from diverse disciplines and backgrounds to learn how microfabrication technologies can be applied to biomaterial synthesis to harness bio-inspired effectors to create new biomimetic materials that will widely impact biomedical science. Two M.S. students in biomedical engineering were trained with this project. The project also contributed to the training of two Ph.D. students. An undergraduate research team was also trained in cross-disciplinary research. Over 20 undergraduate students work with Janus particles through Biobots Vertically Integrated Project Team. The goals of this team is to utilize multifunctional particles to perform motion, sensing, and adhesion to mimic microrobots. This research also developed student entrepreneurship education through the Georgia Tech Inventure Prize. One student team presented their work at the 2016 Inventure Prize quarter final round. One provisional patent has been filed in improving the production of cell products through the selection of highly secreting cells.

 

 


Last Modified: 07/28/2021
Modified by: Todd Sulchek
